citations.narrative:
The facility is not maintaining adequate records of acquisition and disposition. Cage cards are used for acquisition records
for litters of puppies; however, they do not contain all of the required information such as: individual puppy identification
numbers, gender of each puppy, color, and date of disposition as required by the Animal Welfare Act Regulations subpart
2.75(a)(1)(i-ix).
Additionally, not all of the APHIS 7006 Record of Disposition forms evaluated during the inspection are being filled out
completely. There are 4 forms dated 2/20/25 (3) and 3/11/25 (1) that are missing required information found in the
Regulations under 2.75(a)(1)(i-ix), including the name and address of the person who purchased the dog and whether or
not that person is licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and State and the driver’s license number of the
person who purchased the dog, and the method of disposition (sale, donation, etc). Accurate record keeping is essential
so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the movement of dogs into and out of the facility, especially in cases of
loss or theft.
Correct by ensuring each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records for forms which fully and correctly disclose the
information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or which is transported, sold, or
otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born to any animal while in his or her control.

Five puppies did not have access to water. The puppies were in two temporary housing enclosures (one housing two
Cavapoos and two Yorkipoos, and one enclosure housing one Cockapoo) and so, the licensee didn't think they needed
water for that short period of time (a few hours). The enclosures had neither a water bowl nor an automatic waterer. The
licensee provided the puppies with water when asked to by the inspector. The puppies showed little to no interest in the
water. Access to water is necessary to prevent dehydration, especially in young puppies who may not have a lot of
stamina yet. Correct by ensuring potable water is continually provided to all dogs and puppies at all times.

The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for vaccinations in adult dogs. The Animal Welfare Act
(AWA) requires vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs, including rabies, distemper, and parvovirus.
The facility’s PVC prescribes for the rabies vaccine to be given according to label directions for adult dogs. None of the
adult dogs at the facility are up to date on the rabies vaccines required by the AWA. Failure to follow the PVC for
vaccinations leaves the dogs susceptible to diseases, which, if contracted, would cause pain, distress, and suffering. It is
also important for breeding dogs to be vaccinated because they will pass immunity from vaccines onto their offspring.
Correct by administering all of the vaccines required by the Animal Welfare Act (distemper, parvovirus, and rabies) in
accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations.

There is no medical record for a dog being treated for an ear problem. A physical exam by the veterinarian dated 4/12/25
identified female French Bulldog #2612 had a left ear problem. The dog was prescribed Posatex to be given once a day
for 7 days. The licensee reports he is applying the medicine; however, he has not created a medical record to reflect this.
Accurate medical record keeping ensures adequate veterinary care can be assessed by USDA officials during inspection.
Facilities must keep copies of medical records when a problem is identified which include the date and description of the
problem, exam findings, test results, plan for treatment and care and treatment procedures performed when appropriate.
Correct by ensuring the facility document all medical treatments for dogs.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 13, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity cannot continue under your existing USDA license after today (4/14/2025) as it expires today.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility is not maintaining adequate records of acquisition and disposition. Cage cards are used for acquisition records 
for litters of puppies; however, they do not contain all of the required information such as: individual puppy identification 
numbers, gender of each puppy, color, and date of disposition as required by the Animal Welfare Act Regulations subpart 
2.75(a)(1)(i-ix).  
 
Additionally, not all of the APHIS 7006 Record of Disposition forms evaluated during the inspection are being filled out 
completely. There are 4 forms dated 2/20/25 (3) and 3/11/25 (1) that are missing required information found in the 
Regulations under 2.75(a)(1)(i-ix), including the name and address of the person who purchased the dog and whether or 
not that person is licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and State and the driver’s license number of the 
person who purchased the dog, and the method of disposition (sale, donation, etc). Accurate record keeping is essential 
so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the movement of dogs into and out of the facility, especially in cases of 
loss or theft. 
 
Correct by ensuring each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records for forms which fully and correctly disclose the 
information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or which is transported, sold, or 
otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born to any animal while in his or her control. 
3.10(a) 
   
Watering 
Five puppies did not have access to water. The puppies were in two temporary housing enclosures (one housing two 
Cavapoos and two Yorkipoos, and one enclosure housing one Cockapoo) and so, the licensee didn't think they needed 
water for that short period of time (a few hours). The enclosures had neither a water bowl nor an automatic waterer. The 
licensee provided the puppies with water when asked to by the inspector. The puppies showed little to no interest in the 
water. Access to water is necessary to prevent dehydration, especially in young puppies who may not have a lot of 
stamina yet. Correct by ensuring potable water is continually provided to all dogs and puppies at all times. 
3.13(a)(3)  Repeat

Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for vaccinations in adult dogs. The Animal Welfare Act 
(AWA) requires vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs, including rabies, distemper, and parvovirus. 
The facility’s PVC prescribes for the rabies vaccine to be given according to label directions for adult dogs. None of the 
adult dogs at the facility are up to date on the rabies vaccines required by the AWA. Failure to follow the PVC for 
vaccinations leaves the dogs susceptible to diseases, which, if contracted, would cause pain, distress, and suffering. It is 
also important for breeding dogs to be vaccinated because they will pass immunity from vaccines onto their offspring. 
Correct by administering all of the vaccines required by the Animal Welfare Act (distemper, parvovirus, and rabies) in 
accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations. 
3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There is no medical record for a dog being treated for an ear problem. A physical exam by the veterinarian dated 4/12/25 
identified female French Bulldog #2612 had a left ear problem. The dog was prescribed Posatex to be given once a day 
for 7 days. The licensee reports he is applying the medicine; however, he has not created a medical record to reflect this. 
Accurate medical record keeping ensures adequate veterinary care can be assessed by USDA officials during inspection. 
Facilities must keep copies of medical records when a problem is identified which include the date and description of the 
problem, exam findings, test results, plan for treatment and care and treatment procedures performed when appropriate. 
Correct by ensuring the facility document all medical treatments for dogs. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 13, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity cannot continue under your existing USDA license after today (4/14/2025) as it expires today.
